awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Deconvolving the southern South American Pleistocene-Holocene dust production pathways
awd_abstract_narration:
Dust blown from the South American continent into the oceans has been an important source of nutrients for marine organisms and is part of a complex natural system that influences atmospheric CO2 levels over geologic time. Our current understanding of how this system has operated in the past is limited, largely because we have little information on when, where or how dust has been generated on the continent. This project will trace individual grains of wind-blown dust archived in the geologic record of southern South America in order to determine where dust has been produced in the recent past, how it was transported across the continent and then blown into the atmosphere, and how these processes have changed through time and under different climates. The information will help link terrestrial, atmospheric and ocean sciences, refine future climate models, and foster collaborations between U.S. and South American scientists.     

This project will determine sediment sources and transport pathways of central and southern South American loess deposits using single-grain detrital mineral geochronology on silt- to sand-sized sediment. Large observation (i.e., Large-n) U-Pb detrital zircon geochronology will be applied to trace sediments through their production pathways in order to determine the location and relative contribution of dust sources over time. Samples will be collected from the Andes mountains, modern and recent river deposits, and from loess and loessoid units in the foreland basin. These data will help resolve conflicting models of South American dust production derived from previous geochemical and geological approaches, and be used to reconstruct spatio-temporal variations in dust production across the region. Results from this investigation will shed light on hypothesized dust-climate feedback systems operating in this sector of the southern Hemisphere.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merits: The research from this award tested several ideas on the nature of eolian sediment transport in southern South America. This work specifically addressed how rivers moved sediment from the Andes to the Argentine plains where it was then remobilized by the wind. Remobilization by the wind redistributed large volumes of sediment across several areas of southern South America including the Pampean and Chaco plains. A portion of the finer wind-blown sediments entered the atmosphere and ultimately the ocean, and thus, impacted past climates. The research showed that many previous assertions about South American dust transport over the past roughly one million years were unsupported by the testing that occurred during this project. The connections between rivers and wind-blown sediment, observed through sediment provenance analysis, are important because they imply a critical link between precipitation and dust production; the latter is often associated with deserts at low latitudes and glacial outwash at higher latitudes. This research specifically showed a connection between the Río Desaguadero, Pampean Sand Sea (i.e., upper Pleistocene to Holocene vegetation stabilized dunes in the west-central Pampas), and fine-grained upper Pleistocene to Holocene eolian dust (loess) accumulated in the central and eastern Pampas. The eolian portion of this system in the Pampas was primarily driven by lower-level westerly winds. The provenance of fine-grained upper Pleistocene to Holocene eolian dust accumulated in the Chaco is differentiable from the Pampean loess. This observation invalidated previous hypotheses that viewed the Pampean and Chaco eolian systems as a continuum of a single system either originating in the northern Patagonia region or near the border between Bolivia and Argentina. This research also showed that upper Pleistocene and Holocene loess accumulations in the central-eastern Andean foothills were sourced from the west and have disparate provenance from the Pampas and Chaco eolian deposits of similar age. This is important and supports an equatorward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies of several degrees in latitude during intervals of high dust accumulation in the central-eastern Andean foothills. Another finding of this research is the nature of the establishment of the Pampean eolian system during the late Miocene. Data collected for this project show similarities between the eolian system in the Pampas during the late Miocene and the system active during the late Pleistocene and Holocene. This observation supports a new hypothesis that developed from this research. The new hypothesis, noting that the Pampean eolian system and the Chinese Loess Plateau eolian system inhabit the same latitude in their respective hemispheres and both systems developed or expanded significantly during the late Miocene, suggests that atmospheric forcing in both hemispheres caused development of the Pampean eolian system and expansion of the Chinese Loess Plateau during late Miocene climate cooling.

Broader impacts: This project supported the training of one Ph.D. student and more than ten undergraduate students at Clemson University in South Carolina. The research carried out for this project formed the core of a hands-on research course that exposed undergraduate students to advanced research methods and instrumentation in geosciences. In addition, this project was an intellectual collaboration between geoscientists within the State of South Carolina at Clemson University and the University of South Carolina and an international collaboration with geoscientists in Argentina.
